title: Yellen Says She Isn't Predicting Higher Interest Rates
summary: Treasury Secretary walks backs comments she made earlier suggesting that rates might rise. title: 'Lincoln in Private' Review: Conﬁdential Ruminations
summary: In his private writings, Lincoln tested his arguments, and perfected their phrasing, before making them public.. Abraham Lincoln stands among the foremost lyricists of the American experience. His first inaugural address called on a divided citizenry's "better angels" to uphold the sacred inviolability of the Union. His Gettysburg Address envisioned a nation baptized by the blood of battle into "a new birth of freedom." And his second inaugural meditated on a just God chastening a republic of liberty that tolerated slavery.

title: How to Grow a Country Garden Without a Yard
summary: Lack a plot in which to nurture a dreamy profusion of plants and flowers? Dig into container gardening, no land required.. LIKE A BOTANICAL King Midas, Alexander Hoyle turns lifeless pavement into cottage gardens worthy of bucolic Britain. You can barely tell that the fairy-tale patch in front of the garden designer's own London apartment-a profusion that includes foxglove and iris-isn't a patch at all but a group of plantings set atop a mostly flagstone surface (right). The transformative ingredient: containers. Mr. Hoyle fills flower pots with several species, he said, then sets the containers cheek by jowl "to embody the English country garden...romantic, abundant and very floriferous."

title: Inflation Is More of a Threat Than the Fed Says
summary: The velocity of money will increase significantly just as the 27% surge in M2 since the outbreak of the pandemic works its way through the economy.. Regarding Mickey D. Levy and Michael D. Bordo's "The Fed in the Sand as Inflation Threatens" (op-ed, April 27): I have been calling on Fed Chairman Jerome Powell to release his plan to curb the effects of inflation for several months. Last month, I finally heard back from him. He told me that he doesn't want inflation that substantially exceeds 2%, or inflation for a prolonged period.

title: Our Overworked Navy Needs Real Attention
summary: Positioning a fleet between Taiwan and China invites an incident with limitless potential for escalation.. Regarding Seth Cropsey's "America's Naval Strategy Is at Sea" (op-ed, April 28): We might recall the salty Navy aphorism, attributed without firm basis to Adm. Hyman Rickover: "There are two types of ships: submarines and targets." Given the ubiquity of satellite surveillance, secrecy is an anachronism. The assorted missile arrays poised to take out a carrier task force make an entire fleet into a veritable floating Pearl Harbor. Positioning a fleet between Taiwan and China invites an incident with limitless potential for escalation. Were even one ship to be sunk by China, what then would our retaliatory strike provoke? As Adm. Rickover warned: "Unfortunately . . . attempts to limit war have always failed. The lesson of history is when a war starts every nation will ultimately use whatever weapon it has available." A surface Navy in the context of nuclear-armed belligerents is as antiquated as the canvas sail.

title: Kennedy Was First Mover In Cuban Missile Crisis
summary: The placing of the Russian missiles in Cuba was a direct response to President Kennedy's placement of missiles in Turkey.. James Rosen's review of Serhii Plokhy's "Nuclear Folly" (Bookshelf, April 20) opens with the statement that the Cuban missile crisis was something for "which [Nikita] Khrushchev himself was responsible." This is not true. The placing of the Russian missiles in Cuba was a direct response to President Kennedy's placement of missiles in Turkey. When the U.S. objected to the Cuban missiles, Khrushchev offered to withdraw them if the U.S. withdrew the missiles in Turkey. President Kennedy refused and escalated the confrontation. The confrontation was resolved when he agreed to withdraw the missiles in Turkey, provided this was kept secret from the public, and Russia agreed publicly to withdraw the missiles from Cuba.

title: As Decision on Trump Looms, Facebook Preps Its Advertisers

title: Why Patagonia's Baggies Shorts Are Selling Out-and 3 Styles to Buy Instead
summary: The nylon shorts, a brand mainstay since 1982, are growing increasingly popular with a younger generation. If you can't wait for a restock, try these modern-day options.. A FEW WEEKS ago Bryan Koehler, a full-time clothing reseller in Houston, struck gold at his local Goodwill. Mr. Koehler, 26, chanced upon a stash of nearly 50 pairs of Patagonia Baggies, recycled-nylon shorts that come in a kaleidoscope of colors from fluorescent lemon to pine green to solid black. He snatched them up for $5 a pair and, within 48 hours, had sold 40 pairs on the resale site Poshmark at around $40 each. When asked to explain this rapid-fire resale bonanza, he credited the "following" Baggies shorts have attracted. "People are willing to pay [for them]," he said.

title: Letting Go of the Grind
summary: I had to learn the art of just being in order to save myself. On a warm December day at the end of 2019, I sat in my car in the parking lot of Whole Foods, crying my eyes out. I had just received a distressing email from my boss. Our relationship had been challenging for a while, but I stayed on because working as an editor in publishing gave me satisfaction. I knew the job couldn't last and I tried to create an escape plan by taking on other part-time work, including two adjunct positions teaching English, with the hope that I could turn one of them into a new, full-time gig. That's not what happened. Instead, I ground myself down working multiple jobs until I broke.

title: Rachel Cusk's 'Second Place' Might Be the First Pandemic Novel
summary: After her hit Outline trilogy, the author's latest novel gestures toward the emotional tenor of the Covid epidemic while questioning gender norms and further establishing her authorial powers of control.. In Rachel Cusk's novels and nonfiction, it's not unusual for a character to be in the process of renovating a house. In a 2016 essay, "Making House: Notes on Domesticity," Cusk describes remodeling her flat in London, "driven to what appeared to be the brink of mental and physical collapse." For Cusk, 54, home often serves as a backdrop for the expression of artistic and philosophical positions. "It always felt to me like if I wanted to live as a writer, I had to almost create, as a woman, the conditions for me as a writer to be able to exist," she says.

title: Mother's Day Gift Ideas for the Mom Who Needs a Break
summary: The best gift ideas to give Mom a blissful sense of escape-even if she's still stuck at home. She's spent about 14 months going on mute to handle the meltdowns, the missing keys-the casually posed question about whether there's anything else for dinner. For Mother's Day, she would like to (kindly) mute you. Presenting 39 gift ideas from WSJ. Magazine's mom-editors to give the maternal figure in your life a blissful sense of escape-even if she's still stuck at home.

title: Patriots Owner Robert Kraft Buys Hamptons Beach House for $43 Million
summary: The billionaire purchased the Meadow Lane property from New York real-estate developer Nir Meir. New England Patriots owner Robert Kraft has bought a tony Hamptons property in an off-market deal for $43 million, according to two people familiar with the deal. The transaction is one of the largest to close in the wealthy beach destination so far this year.

title: Suburban Homes and Retail Are the Budding New Office Hotspot
summary: Startups and landlords are banking that even after the pandemic, people will want a place to work remotely beyond their living rooms. Real-estate companies are transforming suburban residences and retail spaces into offices, betting that the pandemic will increase demand for workspaces in these neighborhoods.

title: U.S. Travelers Say 'Aloha' Again, Bringing Relief to Hawaiian Hotels
summary: Occupancy rates near 50%, lower than the U.S. average but a notable uptick from 12% a year earlier. HONOLULU-Hawaii's hospitality industry is slowly returning to life, belatedly joining the mainland's rebound as the Covid-19 vaccine rollout and fewer travel restrictions are helping to fill the state's restaurants and hotel beds.

title: The NBA Star Who Fixed His Shot-and the Knicks
summary: Julius Randle was one of the league's worst 3-point shooters. Now he's one of the best. And you thought the Knicks being good was crazy.. One year ago, the New York Knicks couldn't win and Julius Randle couldn't shoot, and there wasn't much reason to believe that either would change soon.

title: KKR Swings to a Profit
summary: Private-equity firm posts quarterly revenue of $4.56 billion, compared with negative revenue a year ago. Private-equity firm KKR & Co. reported a profit in the latest quarter as it reported positive investment income and revenue.

title: Deluge of Debt Is Tied to Carbon Emissions and Diversity
summary: Critics say incentives and penalties embedded in 'ratchet' loans meant to spur environmental and social change are too small to matter. BlackRock Inc., Bud owner Anheuser-Busch InBev NV and a plastic packaging maker in Portugal are among a flood of borrowers using financial carrots and sticks to improve their performance on things such as the environment and boardroom diversity. The sticks, complain some investors, don't leave much of a mark.

title: Consumer Lenders Face a New Challenge: Each Other
summary: Lenders awash in cheap funding face no credit issues for now, but that might not last. Things are very good for consumer lenders right now. Maybe too good.

title: This Rail Merger Could Become Quite Expensive
summary: Canadian National's higher bid for Kansas City Southern gives it upper hand, but exposes it to broad financial risk if approval falls through. The scrap between two Canadian railroads for Kansas City Southern is getting ugly. It could also get very expensive.

title: The Taiwanese Chip Champion Shaking Qualcomm's Tree
summary: MediaTek has fared well during the chip shortage and its stock has skyrocketed. The technological rivalry between China and the U.S. has drawn attention to the world's chip factory, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Another semiconductor company on the island has also thrived as tensions have escalated.

title: That Vacated Sears Store May Reopen as a Public School
summary: Mall owners find charter schools make good tenants in many spaces left empty by departing big-box retailers. Mall owners have hit on a new way to fill gaping holes left by failed department stores and other departing big-box tenants: hosting public schools in need of more space.

title: In New Orleans, a Preview of a Possible Summer Travel Boom
summary: Resume Subscription. NEW ORLEANS-For much of the past year, this city's Frenchmen Street has been largely silent, the result of pandemic-related lockdowns and a nosedive in tourism. "Butt naked," is how brass-band leader James Williams described Frenchmen, known for its typically bustling all-hours live-music venues.

title: Clorox's Move to Provide Adjusted EPS Raises Concerns
summary: The non-GAAP metric will increase transparency, company CFO says. Clorox Co. 's decision to break out adjusted earnings per share is drawing concern from some analysts who view the change to how the consumer company measures its corporate value as potentially misleading.

title: Negative Rates Push Cautious Germans Into the Stock Market
summary: Negative bank rates and booming U.S. stocks like Amazon, Tesla-even GameStop-embolden investors. Michael Schacht, 70 years old, is a typical German saver. Risk-averse, the clothing-shop owner kept the equivalent of $300,000 in a local bank in a small town near Hamburg.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Lawmakers Urge Probe of Amazon's Pursuit of Pentagon Contract
summary: Sen. Mike Lee and Rep. Ken Buck say Amazon might have violated antitrust law in seeking JEDI cloud-computing deal ultimately won by Microsoft. Two Republican lawmakers are pressing the attorney general to investigate potential anticompetitive behavior by Amazon . com Inc. in its pursuit of a major government cloud-computing contract, according to letters reviewed by The Wall Street Journal.

title: FBI Shoots Armed Man Outside CIA Headquarters
summary: The shooting ended hourslong standoff between the man and law enforcement. The FBI said that at least one agent shot and wounded a man carrying a weapon outside the headquarters of the Central Intelligence Agency, ending an hourslong standoff Monday.

title: Government Bankruptcy Lawyer Says LaPierre Failed to Provide NRA Oversight
summary: A government lawyer said a monthlong trial established that NRA management should be removed or the group's chapter 11 case thrown out. A Justice Department lawyer said that National Rifle Association leader Wayne LaPierre has failed to provide adequate oversight of the gun-rights organization and that management should be removed or curtailed if a bankruptcy judge allows the NRA to remain in chapter 11.
